body:
2015-07-29 21:47 GMT-04:00 dbaroncelli <notifications@github.com>:

> @hyangah <https://github.com/hyangah>, I found some other issues with the
> plugin:
>
> 1)
>
>    - if I run the "gobind" task from the AndroidStudio IDE, I get the
>    error /var/go/bin/gomobile: no Go tool on $PATH
>
> Does your PATH param in the hello/build.gradle include the path to your go
tool?


>    - if instead I run from the command line: ./gradlew gobind there are
>    no errors and an .aar file gets created in the Android project directory
>    with the name of the Android project, and not with the name of the Go
>    package I specified in the build.gradle file (is it intended?)
>
> What is your project structure, and from what module did you import the
gobind plugin?
In the example, the 'hello' module's build.gradle imports the gobind plugin.

>
>
> 2)
> In order to be able to use the functions defined in the Go package, I then
> add the .aar file to the project (is this what is supposed to be done?).
>
When I do that, a subdirectory with the same name of the .aar file (and
> hence the name of the Android project) gets created and the .aar file is
> moved from the project directory to this subdirectory.
> I can now successfully access all the Go functions defined in this .aar
> which has been moved to such subdirectory.
>
No. If you use the gradle plugin you don't need to add .aar file. Just
delete all .aar file and replace the build.gradle of the .aar module
directory with what's similar to the
example/bind/android/hello/build.gradle.


> 3)
> If I run "./gradlew gobind" again, an .aar file gets added again to the
> project directory, but the .arr file of the subdirectory (which is the one
> linked to the Android project) doesn't get updated
>
> The gradle plugin is new (I checked it in last week) and it seems that it
needs proper documentation.

Until the documentation is available, for now, it may be easier to follow
what the gomobile package doc says - i.e. utilize Android Studio's .aar
import, and run 'gomobile bind' tool with -o option to overwrite the .aar
file **in your android studio project's aar module directory**. Sorry for
inconvenience.
